title: Igor Dobrovolski
text:
Igor Ivanovich Dobrovolski (, , "Ihor Ivanovych Dobrovolskyi"; born 27 August 1967) is a <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and a former player. He is the head coach of <a href="FC%20Dinamo-Auto%20Tiraspol">FC Dinamo-Auto Tiraspol</a>.
He started his career in the <a href="Moldavian%20SSR">Moldavian SSR</a>, then played in the <a href="Russian%20SFSR">Russian SFSR</a>, Spain, Switzerland, Italy, France and Germany before retiring in <a href="Moldova">Moldova</a>. He never played in the <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> or independent <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>.
Club career.
Born in Markivka, <a href="Rozdilna%20Raion">Rozdilna Raion</a>, <a href="Odessa%20Oblast">Odessa Oblast</a>, <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>, Dobrovolski trained at <a href="Tiraspol">Tiraspol</a> <a href="Children%20and%20Youth%20Sport%20School">Children and Youth Sport School</a> N4 in Moldavian SSR in early years (now in <a href="Transnistria">Transnistria</a>). During his extensive career he played for <a href="FC%20Zimbru%20Chi%C5%9Fin%C4%83u">Nistru Chişinău</a>, <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Moscow">Dynamo Moscow</a>, <a href="CD%20Castell%C3%B3n">Castellón</a>, <a href="Servette%20FC">Servette</a>, <a href="Genoa%20C.F.C.">Genoa</a>, <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a>, <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Madrid">Atlético Madrid</a>, <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a> and <a href="CS%20Tiligul-Tiras%20Tiraspol">Tiligul Tiraspol</a>.
International career.
Dobrovolski played for three different national teams: <a href="USSR%20national%20football%20team">USSR</a> at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Olympic Games</a> where he was a gold medal winner and finished second top goal scorer with six goals (including one in the Gold Medal game itself); <a href="Rom%C3%A1rio">Romário</a> scored seven but <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> lost in the final to <a href="USSR%20national%20football%20team">USSR</a>. He was also part, with the same team, of the <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a>, representing afterwards the <a href="CIS%20national%20football%20team">CIS</a> at <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201992">UEFA Euro 1992</a> and <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">Russia</a> at <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201996">Euro 1996</a>. He scored CIS's only goal in <a href="UEFA%20Euro%201992">UEFA Euro 1992</a>, in a 1–1 draw against Germany.
Four players have had the honour of scoring at least one goal in five successive matches at the Men's Olympic Football Tournament – Igor Dobrovolski (USSR in 1988), <a href="Ottmar%20Hitzfeld">Ottmar Hitzfeld</a> (FR Germany in 1972), <a href="Milan%20Gali%C4%87">Milan Galić</a> (Yugoslavia in 1960) and <a href="Adolfo%20Baloncieri">Adolfo Baloncieri</a> (Italy in 1928). Only Dobrovolski and Galić actually claimed gold.
Coaching career.
At 39 years old he was coaching <a href="CS%20Tiligul-Tiras%20Tiraspol">Tiligul Tiraspol</a> in the 2005–06 season, and then took over the <a href="Moldova%20national%20football%20team">Moldova national football team</a> for the qualification to <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">UEFA Euro 2008</a>, with a view to a two-year extension to his contract if he was successful.
In December 2007, he signed a new contract with Moldova. He was allowed to coach any club until the start of <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28UEFA%29">2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)</a>. On 16 October 2009, Dobrovolski announced his resignation.
